guide.title: Gentoo Qmail+vPopMail+Courier-IMAP+more
guide.abstract: This guide shows you how to setup a fully-featured Qmail-based virtual mail solution, with spam and virus protection. Included: Qmail, Vpopmail, MySQL, SpamAssassin, Courier-IMAP (IMAP, IMAP+SSL, POP3, POP3+SSL), qmail-scanner, antivirus.

chapter.title: "Prepare to abandon ship!" - Cleaning up your system

body.p: For the purposes of this guide, we assume that you have only a basic mail setup in Gentoo at this point, such as only SSMTP or Nullmailer.
If this is not the case, you may have to adapt some of the instructions.
Every Gentoo system has an MTA (Mail Transfer Agent) installed by default. SSMTP is the default for most platforms, but Nullmailer is also becoming more common.
We need to remove the existing MTA before we can install a new one.
body.pre:
# emerge -p qmail
These are the packages that I would merge, in order:
Calculating dependencies ...done! [blocks B ] net-mail/ssmtp ("virtual/mta" from pkg net-mail/qmail-1.03-r12) [ebuild N ] net-mail/qmail-1.03-r12 (The above output may be somewhat different depending on what you have installed already)
body.p: Ok, so we can see that we have net-mail/ssmtp installed and it's blocking us from installing qmail. We don't want SSMTP, so lets get rid of it!
body.pre:
# emerge -C ssmtp
net-mail/ssmtp selected: 2.60.4 protected: none omitted: none (output from removing here)
body.p: We have now removed SSMTP from our system. At this point NO email is being delivered on the system.

This document assumes that you have the following USE flags enabled: mysql pam nls fam ssl. You may also be interested in the clearpasswd USE flag. By default, vpopmail will not store cleartext passwords, however as a sysadmin, you may wish to have cleartext passwords in the database for debugging and reference. (Possibly cleartext passwords required for (CRAM|DIGEST)-MD5 ?)
This document deals with >=net-mail/qmail-1.03-r12, >=net-mail/courier-imap-2.1.2-r1 presently. These packages are in ACCEPT_KEYWORDS="~x86" and as such they are not available to x86 yet.

chapter.title: "Good evening, I'll be your MTA tonight" - Qmail

body.p: Now that our system is ready for it, let's install qmail!
body.pre:
# emerge qmail (At this point qmail and all of it's dependancies will be installed) ... * To setup qmail to run out-of-the-box on your system, run: * ebuild /var/db/pkg/net-mail/qmail-1.03-r12/qmail-1.03-r12.ebuild config
* To start qmail at boot you have to add svscan to your startup * and create the following links : * ln -s /var/qmail/supervise/qmail-send /service/qmail-send * ln -s /var/qmail/supervise/qmail-smtpd /service/qmail-smtpd
* To start the pop3 server as well, create the following link : * ln -s /var/qmail/supervise/qmail-pop3d /service/qmail-pop3d
* Additionally, the QMTP and QMQP protocols are supported, and can be started as: * ln -s /var/qmail/supervise/qmail-qmtpd /service/qmail-qmtpd * ln -s /var/qmail/supervise/qmail-qmqpd /service/qmail-qmqpd
* Additionally, if you wish to run qmail right now, you should run this before anything else: * source /etc/profile ...
body.p: For the moment, we are going to ignore most of these instructions, as we want to do a bit more setup first, and avoid restarting qmail.
body.pre: # ebuild /var/db/pkg/net-mail/qmail-1.03-r12/qmail-1.03-r12.ebuild config eutils fixheadtails Your fully qualified host name is cherenkov-int. Putting $hostname into control/me... Putting $hostname into control/defaultdomain... Putting $hostname into control/plusdomain... Putting $hostname into control/locals... Putting $hostname into control/rcpthosts... Now qmail will refuse to accept SMTP messages except to $hostname. Make sure to change rcpthosts if you add hosts to locals or virtualdomains! * Accepting relaying by default from all ips configured on this machine. ssl Creating a self-signed ssl-cert: Generating a 1024 bit RSA private key ..........................++++++ .................++++++ writing new private key to '//var/qmail/control/servercert.pem' ----- You are about to be asked to enter information that will be incorporated into your certificate request. What you are about to enter is what is called a Distinguished Name or a DN. There are quite a few fields but you can leave some blank For some fields there will be a default value, If you enter '.', the field will be left blank. ----- The following values are for MY location, you should enter your own details instead! Country Name (2 letter code) [AU]:CA State or Province Name (full name) [Some-State]:British Columbia Locality Name (eg, city) []:Burnaby Organization Name (eg, company) [Internet Widgits Pty Ltd]:Orbis-Terrarum Networks I recommend that you leave this value at "Qmail SMTP server" due to the nature of SSL certificates Organizational Unit Name (eg, section) []:Qmail SMTP server This MUST be a hostname that resolves to the IP of your server Common Name (eg, YOUR name) []:mail.orbis-terrarum.net These should be the address of the person administering the server Email Address []:robbat2@orbis-terrarum.net * If You want to have a signed cert, do the following: * openssl req -new -nodes -out req.pem \ * -keyout /var/qmail/control/servercert.pem * Send req.pem to your CA to obtain signed_req.pem, and do: * cat signed_req.pem >> /var/qmail/control/servercert.pem
body.note: Qmail's is fussy in that it doesn't let simple self-signed certificates get used for SSL/TLS communications, the certificate has to be signed by some CA, and you need to give it all of the certifcate chain in a single file. Due to this, I leave it out for the moment.
